content: raglan crop top raglan is the term for a top that is one solid piece with armholes that extend diagonally into the collar which is how this blouse is worked- crocheting in the round from top to bottom the pattern is versatile enough that making it in any size and adding sleeves or body length doesn t require complicated math and the best part is there aren t any fussy panels to sew together plus you can try it on as you go this is my go-to way of crocheting tops when i don t want to worry about making different pieces that need to be attached it works especially well for sweaters that are relaxed fit and with ombre yarns for continuity of the gradient project time ~6-10 hours materials us size i/ 5 5mm hook #4 medium weight yarn- 1 7oz skein is enough to make a small/medium size tapestry needle & scissors things to keep in mind you can use whatever hook size and yarn weight you like and i encourage you to experiment with that so you can familiarize yourself with gauge which is stitch size based on thickness of yarn size of hook and tightness of stitch because you will organically learn how to adjust a pattern to get your desired fit at the beginning of each double_crochet row i like to do a stacked single_crochet which is placing a single_crochet into the first st then inserting your hook into the left vertical loop of that same single_crochet and making another single crochet hence two single crochets stacked to create a double_crochet stitch this gives a neater seam than the usual beginning chain 3 because it blends in better as a stitch rather than a chain of 3 but this is totally optional abbreviations chain- chain sts- stitches single_crochet- single_crochet half_double_crochet- half_double_crochet double_crochet- double_crochet decrease- decrease by making 2 double crochets together slip_stitch- slip_stitch 2dc- work 2 double crochets into same stitch v_stitch- double_crochet chain 2 double_crochet in the same stitch pattern you re going to make a foundation chain and attach the ends to crochet in the round starting at the collar then down continuously without turning increases are worked at the 4 v stitches in each corner ie sides of the arm holes you can close them by stopping increases once it s long enough then continuing to work around the sweater body for longer sleeves attach yarn directly at the base of the arm holes and work in the round down to the wrist body single_crochet foundation chain 42 and without twisting chain join ends with slip_stitch to first st half_double_crochet around 42 double_crochet 2dc around ending with 1dc in first st 64 double_crochet 10 v_stitch double_crochet 10 v_stitch double_crochet 20 v_stitch double_crochet 10 v_stitch double_crochet 10 slip_stitch to first st 68 from now on v stitches will be worked into chain 2 spaces of the previous v stitches double_crochet 11 v_stitch double_crochet 12 v_stitch double_crochet 22 v_stitch double_crochet 12
